resistance movie quote emancipated slave

Depending on which "resistance" you're looking for, here are the most relevant movie quotes and historical references:

From the Movie _

[Emancipation](https://www.google.com/search?q=Emancipation&kgmid=/g/11rs2n1smq&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwicyq--n8-SAxWhtokEHV70BSAQ3egRegQIAxAB)

_ (2022)

This film follows Peter, an enslaved man who escapes through the Louisiana swamps to join the Union Army. It heavily emphasizes the concept of mental and physical resistance. 

- **"They can't break me. Not my spirit. Not my mind. Emancipation means your mind as well, not just your body."** — This [Vanity Fair](https://www.vanityfair.com/hollywood/2022/11/emancipation-inside-will-smiths-unsparing-new-slave-drama) highlight captures the film's core theme of internal liberation as a form of resistance.
- **"I will look in triumph at my enemies."** — A recurring sentiment of defiance used in the film's marketing and dialogue. 

From the Movie _

[Resistance](https://www.google.com/search?q=Resistance&kgmid=/g/11gwn6s0jr&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwicyq--n8-SAxWhtokEHV70BSAQ3egRegQIBhAB)

_ (2020)

This film tells the true story of **Marcel Marceau**, who joined the French Resistance during WWII to save Jewish orphans. One poignant discussion on the meaning of resistance occurs between characters: 

- **"If you want to resist, we have to make sure more Jews survive."** — Marceau argues that saving lives is a more powerful form of resistance than simply killing the enemy.
- **"We can slow them down! We can make it impossible for them in France."** — A call to action for active, physical sabotage against the occupation. 

Historical Context on Resistance

- **Henry Highland Garnet (1843):** In his "Address to the Slaves of the United States," he famously declared, **"Let your motto be resistance! resistance! RESISTANCE! No oppressed people have ever secured their liberty without resistance."**.
- **Frederick Douglass:** Often associated with the idea that **"The moment the slave resolves that he will no longer be a slave, his fetters fall,"** emphasizing that freedom is a mental state. 

Are you looking for a **specific scene** or a quote from a **different film** (like _

[The Woman King](https://www.google.com/search?q=The+Woman+King&kgmid=/g/11l49hppx9&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwicyq--n8-SAxWhtokEHV70BSAQ3egRegQICxAC)

_ or _

[12 Years a Slave](https://www.google.com/search?q=12+Years+a+Slave&kgmid=/m/0h32y7j&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwicyq--n8-SAxWhtokEHV70BSAQ3egRegQICxAE)

_)?

Yea the 2020 bro but I want the quote its a pretty distinct one where he says "they hate us because they are conditioned to believe we killed jesus" and the lady is basically like "no they hhate you because the jews emancipated themselves"

In the 2020 film 

**

[Resistance](https://www.google.com/search?q=Resistance&kgmid=/g/11gwn6s0jr&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwjf-sDYn8-SAxUKrokEHaM1ApwQ3egRegYIAQgCEAI)

**, the exchange you're thinking of takes place between **Marcel Marceau** (Jesse Eisenberg) and **Emma** (Clémence Poésy). 

The scene centers on their differing perspectives on why the Jewish people are targeted and how to best "resist" the Nazi occupation:

- **Marcel:** "They hate us because for centuries they were told that we killed Christ."
- **Emma:** (Correcting him) "No. They hate you because the Jews **emancipated themselves**. They are afraid because they can't see who you pray to." 

Key Context of the Quote

- **The Argument:** Marcel initially attributes the hatred to the ancient "deicide" trope (the idea that Jews killed Jesus). Emma argues that the true source of the hatred is Jewish **emancipation and autonomy**—the fact that they are a free, self-governed people whose inner convictions are invisible and therefore "threatening" to the oppressor.
- **The Philosophy of Resistance:** This conversation sets up the film's core theme: whether resistance means killing Nazis or ensuring the survival of the next generation. Marcel famously concludes later in the film, **"If you want to resist, we have to make sure more Jews survive."** 

You can find more about this specific dialogue and its historical themes in reviews from [The Spectator](https://spectator.com/article/a-true-story-that-never-feels-true-resistance-reviewed/) and [Plugged In](https://www.pluggedin.com/movie-reviews/resistance/).
